Charging YearbOoks
To Stop January 10
Charging the Hullabaloo on
student bills will stop on January 10, it was announced Tuesday by Editor
Abrams.
After that date, cold cash must
accompany all orders for the
yearbook. The list of those charging the Hullabaloo will be sent
to the registrar at that time.
The editorial staff of the yearbook is hoping for a successful
Yearbook, and according to Abrams, "We hope to be out by the
first of August. We are running at
least three and one-half months
ahead of last year's schedule."
.There may be a few flies in the
Ointment,
however, . continued
Abrams, as business managers of
Various organizations have been
slew in paying for pages. "We'd
appreciate ,it if they'd pay soon."
.eventy-five boys have not
Picked up last year's yearbooks
Which they have ordered and paid
for.
Abrams stated that these
books should be picked up at
the Barn
between noon and 1 p.m.

DSRC May Become
"Puppet" Organization
The Dormitory Student Representative Council is faced with ,a
situation which will lead to its
becoming a "puppet" organization,
according to Carleton Jones, president of the DSRC.
The system of having counselors
in the. dormitories has been put
into effect this year to a greater
extent than previously (at least
for recent years.) These counselors
(Messrs. Marshall Turner, James
Phinney, Clyde Stallings, and Wilson Fewster) were supposed to
handle problems that the dorm
vice-presidents felt could not be
handled adequately by the house
representatives.
Minor problems would be dealt
with by house representatives or,
if necessary, the vice-president of
the dorm concerned. The above
was the system described to the
DSRC by Mr. Turner, head counselor, at a meeting earlier this

are going to the counselors directly (or counselors are seeking out
men whose academic status is
shaky, i.e., who have received informals). The counselors have received "a considerable number" of
complaints that there is so much
noise that study is impossible. The
counselors decided to take action
and at this writing plan to see
Dean G. Wilson Shaffer.
The DSRC feels that such a
move "cuts us out of the picture"
and at Tuesday's meeting expressed a determination "to take action." Said Jones, "The administration has changed its policy as
regards student affairs . .. (the
dorm men) should realize they're
sitting under an axe."

national graduate scientific fraternity, at 8:30 tonight in Shriver
Hall on the subject "The New
Protocracies."
Because of a growing public
demand this week to hear. Dr.
Mead, the site of lecture has been
changed from Levering to Shriver
Hall, and is now open to the public.
Bruce Jacobson, chairman of
the Gamma Alpha committee,
stated that Dr. Mead was selected
for th,- annual
ture "in order to
enrich the cultural interests of
the audience and to bring new
ideas to the campus."
Dr. Mead, assc _iate curator of
ethnology at the American Museum of National History in New
York, has received degrees from
De Pauw Unive-sity and Barnard
College, earning her B.A. at the

latter.
Dr. Mead to-k her M.A. and
doctorate at Columbia University.
From 1925 to 1926, she was a Fellow of the National Research
Council in Samoa. In 1926 she
became assistant curator of ethnology at the American Museum
and was promoted to associate
curator in 1942.
'Male And Female'
Among her books besides "Corn..
ing of Age in Samoa" are "Growing Up in New Guinea," "Male
and Female," "Soviet Attitudes
Toward Authority," which was
co-authored by Frances Macgregor, and "Growth and Culture: A
Photographic Study of Balinese
Childhood."
Gamma Alpha sponsors one
lecture per year and meets every
other week.

What will you have to show for,yourself?
How much will you have contributed in
answer to the pressing demands of an
unbelievably exciting period in engineering achievement? How satisfying
your progress and your rewards?
The coming decade is, for you, a time
of transition. In whatever field you
choose to pursue a career, your record
of advancement from neophyte to veteran will not depend on ability alone.
For ... without ample opportunities
to demonstrate your talents, you cannot prove your potential value in any
industry.
Today, at Sikorsky Aircraft, the
challenge is a mighty one. Solutions to
the intricate problems of advanced ro-

tary wing aircraft will have great bearing on military and commercial progress in the years just ahead. To help
provide the right answers, more engineers with foresight and vision are
needed.
Challenging projects, excellent facili=
ties, creative freedom, recognition of
proficiency, merited promotions and rewards, liberal company policies inclined toward family well-being ..
ALL contribute importantly to a young
engineer's success. Your career at
Sikorsky Aircraft, reviewed ten years
hence, would doubtless reveal a most
satisfactory record, both personally
and professionally.

this plan was abandoned because of plans for a road which
is eventually to be built through
the prospective spot.
Suggestion Vetoed
The next suggestion was to
place the monument to the north
of the main entrance to Gilman
Hall, but this was not acceptable
to the Gilman architecture, and
as a result, the present location
was decided upon.
The base stone upon which the
facsimile of the ODK key rests
was obtained through the Plant
Manager's office, and the key was
acquired three years ago from
the national organization.
The black-top walk, which passes in front of the monument, was
contributed by the Cambell Construction Company, and the five
laurel bushes surrounding the
monument by the Towson Nurseries.
The significance of the five
laurel bushes is two-fold. First,
they represent the five indespensible qualities for membership in
the organization—character, leadership and service in campus life,
scholarship, fellowship, and consecration to democratic ideals.
Bushes Signify
The bushes also signify the five
areas or phases of campus life in
which ODE stresses achievement
—scholarship, athletics, social and
religious affairs, publications, and
speech, music, and dramatic arts,

With a starting five that averages 6' 3" in height, the Blue Jay
Freshmen basketball team opens
its 1955-'56 season tomorrow evening at 7 p.m. against Baltimore
Junior College.
This preliminary game, which
will'be followed by the varsity contest, will be' the only action for
the fledgling Jays before the
Christmas holidays. January 7 is
the date of the Jays' second game
of the season, a tilt with the Towson Teachers.
Plans Tall Squad
Frosh Basketball Mentor Bob
Scott plans to keep as much height
as possible on the court at all
times. He feels that his tall boys

are effective scorers, good rebounders, and possess sufficient
speed.
The -starting unit of the Jays
is led by Dick Weinstein, 6'6"
center. Weinstein is a definite
scoring threat and a good rebounder, according to Scott.
The forward positions will be
manned by Erv Sekulow and Joel
Miller, a former high school star
from Minneapolis. "Both of these
cagers stand over 6'6" in height
and are among the best rebounders
on the squad,' said Scott. Billy
Morrill, who was one of the top
point producers in the Baltimore
high school ranks last year, is

giving both of the starters a battle for one of the forward posts.
Riley, Bernstein Rate
According to Scott, Pat Riley
and Ed Bernstein have performed
well in the backcourt and probably will open the season as the
starting guards. Riley, according
to the youthful mentor, has been
directing the Jay offense and has
shown court leadership.
Backing up the starting five
and pressing them for the top
spots are Bob Williams, Chuck
Loughran, Pete Greenberg, Morris
Jones, and Al Seivold.

"The Bird," as the Hopkins
Blue-Jay mascot is called by the
members of the Boosters club, • -ill
soon be in New York City to undergo general repairs, according
to its custodian, Penn Lupovich.
Bearing no official name other
than "The Bird," the Blue Jay
was purchased by the Boosters
Club early last year as a school
mascot. Lupovich stated that he
was not sure of the exact purchase price, but that he felt that
it could not be replaced for less
than $250.

Chub have been seen wearing the
egstume at football and lacrosse
games and at pep rally.s. Lupovich
hopes to have basketball games
included in the list of "The Bird's"
appearances in the near future. He
is now trying to get the same person to don the outfit in both the
fall and spring.

Bird" has movable eyes and a
movable beak, and according to
Lupovich, "is quite cold in the
winter to be dancing around in."

DSRC May Become
"Puppet" Organization
The Dormitory Student Representative Council is faced with ,a
situation which will lead to its
becoming a "puppet" organization,
according to Carleton Jones, president of the DSRC.
The system of having counselors
in the. dormitories has been put
into effect this year to a greater
extent than previously (at least
for recent years.) These counselors
(Messrs. Marshall Turner, James
Phinney, Clyde Stallings, and Wilson Fewster) were supposed to
handle problems that the dorm
vice-presidents felt could not be
handled adequately by the house
representatives.
Minor problems would be dealt
with by house representatives or,
if necessary, the vice-president of
the dorm concerned. The above
was the system described to the
DSRC by Mr. Turner, head counselor, at a meeting earlier this

are going to the counselors directly (or counselors are seeking out
men whose academic status is
shaky, i.e., who have received informals). The counselors have received "a considerable number" of
complaints that there is so much
noise that study is impossible. The
counselors decided to take action
and at this writing plan to see
Dean G. Wilson Shaffer.
The DSRC feels that such a
move "cuts us out of the picture"
and at Tuesday's meeting expressed a determination "to take action." Said Jones, "The administration has changed its policy as
regards student affairs . .. (the
dorm men) should realize they're
sitting under an axe."

Because of a growing public
demand this week to hear. Dr.
Mead, the site of lecture has been

Hall, and is now open to the public.
Bruce Jacobson, chairman of
the Gamma Alpha committee,
stated that Dr. Mead was selected
for th,- annual
ture "in order to
enrich the cultural interests of
the audience and to bring new
ideas to the campus."
Dr. Mead, assc _iate curator of
ethnology at the American Museum of National History in New
York, has received degrees from
De Pauw Unive-sity and Barnard
College, earning her B.A. at the

latter.
Dr. Mead to-k her M.A. and
doctorate at Columbia University.
From 1925 to 1926, she was a Fellow of the National Research
Council in Samoa. In 1926 she
became assistant curator of ethnology at the American Museum
and was promoted to associate
curator in 1942.
'Male And Female'
Among her books besides "Corn..
ing of Age in Samoa" are "Growing Up in New Guinea," "Male
and Female," "Soviet Attitudes
Toward Authority," which was
co-authored by Frances Macgregor, and "Growth and Culture: A
Photographic Study of Balinese
Childhood."
Gamma Alpha sponsors one
lecture per year and meets every
other week.

Suggestion Vetoed
The next suggestion was to
place the monument to the north
of the main entrance to Gilman
Hall, but this was not acceptable
to the Gilman architecture, and
as a result, the present location
was decided upon.
The base stone upon which the
facsimile of the ODK key rests
was obtained through the Plant
Manager's office, and the key was
acquired three years ago from
the national organization.
The black-top walk, which passes in front of the monument, was
contributed by the Cambell Construction Company, and the five
laurel bushes surrounding the
monument by the Towson Nurseries.
The significance of the five
laurel bushes is two-fold. First,
they represent the five indespensible qualities for membership in
the organization—character, leadership and service in campus life,
scholarship, fellowship, and consecration to democratic ideals.
Bushes Signify
The bushes also signify the five
areas or phases of campus life in
which ODE stresses achievement
—scholarship, athletics, social and
religious affairs, publications, and
speech, music, and dramatic arts,

PAGE ELEVEN

With a starting five that averages 6' 3" in height, the Blue Jay
Freshmen basketball team opens
its 1955-'56 season tomorrow evening at 7 p.m. against Baltimore
Junior College.
This preliminary game, which
will'be followed by the varsity contest, will be' the only action for
the fledgling Jays before the
Christmas holidays. January 7 is
the date of the Jays' second game
of the season, a tilt with the Towson Teachers.
Plans Tall Squad
Frosh Basketball Mentor Bob
Scott plans to keep as much height
as possible on the court at all
times. He feels that his tall boys

are effective scorers, good rebounders, and possess sufficient
speed.
The -starting unit of the Jays
is led by Dick Weinstein, 6'6"
center. Weinstein is a definite
scoring threat and a good rebounder, according to Scott.
The forward positions will be
manned by Erv Sekulow and Joel
Miller, a former high school star
from Minneapolis. "Both of these
cagers stand over 6'6" in height
and are among the best rebounders
on the squad,' said Scott. Billy
Morrill, who was one of the top
point producers in the Baltimore
high school ranks last year, is

giving both of the starters a battle for one of the forward posts.
Riley, Bernstein Rate
According to Scott, Pat Riley
and Ed Bernstein have performed
well in the backcourt and probably will open the season as the
starting guards. Riley, according
to the youthful mentor, has been
directing the Jay offense and has
shown court leadership.
Backing up the starting five
and pressing them for the top
spots are Bob Williams, Chuck
Loughran, Pete Greenberg, Morris
Jones, and Al Seivold.

Bird To Go North
For Plumage Repair
"The Bird," as the Hopkins
Blue-Jay mascot is called by the
members of the Boosters club, • -ill
soon be in New York City to undergo general repairs, according
to its custodian, Penn Lupovich.
Bearing no official name other
than "The Bird," the Blue Jay
was purchased by the Boosters
Club early last year as a school
mascot. Lupovich stated that he
was not sure of the exact purchase price, but that he felt that
it could not be replaced for less
than $250.
Weighs Fifty Pounds
Various members of the Boosters
Chub have been seen wearing the
egstume at football and lacrosse
games and at pep rally.s. Lupovich
hopes to have basketball games
included in the list of "The Bird's"
appearances in the near future. He
is now trying to get the same person to don the outfit in both the
fall and spring.
Weighing fifty pounds, "The
Bird" has movable eyes and a
movable beak, and according to
Lupovich, "is quite cold in the
winter to be dancing around in."
Last spring, at the HopkinsUnlversity of Maryland lacrosse
gar,ie, "The Bird's" head was
sq'en by some Maryland students.

kins in June. No damage had been
done to it, and it was accompanied
by a new pair of pants. No word
of explanation was ever received
from Maryland.
"The Bird" will be sent to its
manufacturer within a few weeks
for general repairs necessitated by
wear. Lupovich said that "the
seams need restitching, and the
entire costume is in need of repairs."

All twelve member fraternities
of the IFB plan to hold Christmas parties for underprivileged
children or give Christmas baskets to the needy, according to
Bill Kolomaznik, chairman of the
IFB Public Relations Committee.
Specifically, Alpha Delta Phi
will give baskets as will Alpha
Epsilon Pi, Delta Phi, Phi Kappa
Psi, Phi Epsil9n Pi, and Sigma Phi
Epsilon. -Phi Kappa Psi also went
Thursday to a hospital children's
ward where they distributed gifts
and sang carols.
Delta Upsilon will give a party
at the house for underprivileged
crippled children as it has in the
past. The men will pick up the
children at their homes and return them afterwards. Alpha Tau
Omega will hold a similar affair
Sunday with thirty children from
private homes.
Beta Theata Pi will hold a party
tomorrow afternoon; Kappa Alpha
and Phi Sigma Delta will definitely hold parties for underprivileged
children, although no dates have
